alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for accommodation
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing accommodation for employees
title: Expenses and benefits: accommodation

table.body:
As an employer providing accommodation for your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What's included

As well as the costs of the accommodation itself, this includes:

- Council Tax 
- water and sewerage charges 
- heating, lighting and cleaning 
- repair, maintenance and decoration 
- furniture for daily use 
- staff for upkeep of accommodation, eg gardeners and cleaners
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don't have to report or pay anything to HMRC on the cost of certain types of accommodation.

##If it's domestic or personal
For example, accommodation you provide for your son or daughter if they work in your business is exempt.

##If it's provided by a local council
Accommodation is exempt if a local council provides it on the same terms that it provides housing to non-employees.

##If it's necessary or usually provided for the job
Accommodation at the place of work is exempt if:

- your employees can’t do their work properly without it, eg agricultural workers living on farms
- it's common to provide it for a particular type of job, eg vicars, soldiers or pub managers

If you provide the accommodation to company directors, they have to be either full-time or work for a non-profit or charity organisation and hold less than 5% of the shares.

##If it's needed for security
If you need to provide accommodation to protect an employee because of a special threat to their security, this is exempt.

##Other charges and costs
If the accommodation you provide is exempt, you don't have to report Council Tax, water and sewerage charges to HMRC, or pay National Insurance and tax.

You also don't have to report and pay if you arrange accommodation maintenance contracts with suppliers and:

- you pay the supplier directly
- the accommodation is for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or less a year

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the accommodation you provide isn’t [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-accommodation/whats-exempt "exempt"), you must report it to HMRC. You may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on the accommodation and any related costs, eg Council Tax or upkeep. 

##Accommodation

This includes any accommodation you provide, even if the employee doesn't actually use it (see [technical guidance](/technical-guidance "technical guidance") for details).

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay 
- | - | - | - 
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year  | Report on form P9D, section C | Nothing 
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section D | Pay Class 1A National Insurance on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-accommodation/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit") 
Directors | Report on form P11D, section D | Pay Class 1A National Insurance on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-accommodation/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit")

##Council Tax, water and sewerage charges 

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | - 
Employees who cover the costs and you reimburse them | Add the amount you reimburse to the employee’s earnings | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll 
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year, if you cover the costs directly | Report on form P9D, section A(2) | Nothing
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, if you cover the costs directly | Report on form P11D, section B | Nothing
Directors, if you cover the costs directly | Report on form P11D, section B | Nothing

##Furniture, heating, lighting, maintenance

This covers:

- heating, lighting, cleaning 
- repair, maintenance, decoration 
- furniture for daily use 
- staff for upkeep, eg gardeners, cleaners 

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | - 
Employees who cover the costs and you reimburse them, regardless of earnings | Add the full cost to your employee’s earnings | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance and PAYE tax through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year, if they arrange the supplier contracts but you cover the costs | Fill in P9D, section A(2) | Add the full costs to earnings, and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more, if they arrange the supplier contracts but you cover the costs | Fill in P11D, section M | Add the full costs to earnings, and deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Any employees regardless of earnings, if you arrange the supplier contracts and cover the costs directly  | Fill in P11D, section M | Pay Class 1A National Insurance on the full costs 

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body:
To work out the value of living accommodation follow these steps:

s1. Use the greater of the 'annual value' (as shown in the table below) or the rent you pay. 
s2. If you provide the accommodation only part of the year use that proportion. 
s3. Deduct any rent you get from your employee. 
s4. If the accommodation is shared or only partly used for business use that proportion.

The annual value to use depends on where the property is.

Country | Annual value
- | -
England and Wales | 1973 gross rating value
Northern Ireland | 1976 gross rating value 
Scotland | 1985 gross rating value divided by 2.7
Outside the UK | Annual rental value on the open market

##Properties over £75,000

You must add an additional charge to the standard value. 

To start with you have to calculate the 'cost of the accommodation':

s1. Add anything you spent on improvements to the original buying price. 
s2. Deduct any reimbursements by employees from these amounts. 

If you held an interest in the property 6 years before your employee occupied it and they first occupied it after March 1983, use the value of the property at the time your employee moved in, rather than the original buying price.

To calculate the additional charge do the following: 

s1. Deduct £75,000 from the cost of the accommodation. 
s2. Multiply what's left by the official rate of interest - if you only provide the accommodation for part of the year, use that proportion. 
s3. Deduct any rent you get from the employee. 

$E
**Example**  
Buying price: £175,000  
Gross rating value: £1,000  
Employee rent: £1,250  
Interest rate: 4%  

The standard reportable value is £0, because the rent is more than the annual rating value. 

Additional charge is £3,750:  
£175,000 - £75,000 = £100,000  
£100,000 x 4% = £4,000  
£4,000 - £250 (left over rent from standard value) = £3,750  

Total value to report is £3,750:  
Standard value (£0) + additional charge (£3,750)  
$E
